His leader dudded Mr Howard and Andrew Peacock got the top job.

Senators will also recall that in 1985 Mr Peacock called a meeting of the party and declared all leadership positions vacant. Mr Howard had been working on Mr Peacock's demise and the opposition leader decided to take the matter head on. Mr Peacock called on Mr Howard to declare he would never ever run for the leadership but Mr Howard refusedâof course, he said he would never ever have a goods and services tax. So Mr Peacock pulled on a vote to force Mr Howard's hand but Mr Howard did not have the confidence to nominate; he refused to nominate. Mr Peacock was re-elected but his running mate, Mr Moore, was not. The party decided it wanted Mr Howard as deputy leader.

Senators will also recall the extraordinary scenes that followed, with Andrew Peacock declaring a vote for Howard was a vote against him and he promptly resigned. So Mr Howard, who would not throw his hat in the ring and would not even nominate after there had been a spill of positions, found himself as leader of the party. Then Mr Howard lost the leadership to Mr Peacock in 1989. Remember the front page of the Bulletinâ`Mr 14 per centâwhy does he bother' The Prime Minister had another shot at the top job in 1990 but lost convincingly. He tested the water again after the 1993 election but did not have the gumption to run against John Hewson, who had just lost the unlosable election. He finally returned to the leadership position of the Liberal Party on Australia Day in 1995.

So, as I said, Mr Howard has always been the party's second or third choice and hence he trusts no one. Not only does Mr Howard not trust his ministry or his party he does not trust the Australian community. He is far more comfortable with the politics of division than the politics of consensus. It is a political strategy the Prime Minister has applied on a number of occasions. In August 1988 Mr Howard expressed the view that the number of Asians coming to this country was too great. He made this statement in the context of a debate about multiculturalism and its place in Australian society. On the ABC AM program, Mr Howard was asked:
. . . Mr Howard, is the rate of Asian immigration into Australia too fast?
Mr Howard responded:
I think there are some people who believe it is.
He was then asked what he thought and he said:

. . . I wouldn't like to see it greater . . . I do believe that if in the eyes of some in the community, it's too great, it would be in our immediate term interests, and supportive of social cohesion, if it were slowed down a little . . .

And what was his view on multiculturalism? He said that it was an aimless concept. In 1988 he was happy to take the political course of creating division within the Australian community in pursuit of his political agenda. It was a simple message: there are too many Asians coming to Australia.

In his Future directions document released in December of that year Mr Howard said he wanted to see `one Australia' not an Australia of individual groups. Another simple message: if you want to live in Australia you have to behave like a white European middle class heterosexual. One could be forgiven for thinking that the member for Oxley is a plagiarist.

I must add that Mr Howard was more than happy to let the member for Oxley and her motley crew run their campaign of division and bigotry. This was despite the best efforts of manyâincluding John Laws of 2UEâto get him to speak out against her as the Prime Minister of Australia. John Laws was rightly concerned about the damage she was doing to the social fabric of this community. He wanted the Prime Minister to take a stand. John Laws asked him to act like the Prime Minister of Australia and he would not. And why, because he did not want toâhe saw political benefit in remaining silent. So Ms Hanson and her acolytes parade the misnomer of one nation. It begs the question: what do we call the Howard Liberals? Half a nation?

The manner in which the Prime Minister dealt with the debate over the native title issue provides further and clear evidence that Mr Howard's approach to the Australian waterfront is true to form. On the ABC's 7.30 Report on 4 September last year the Prime Minister said that the problem with native title is:
. . . that the pendulum has swung too far in one direction, particularly after the Wik decision . . .
He then held up a map of Australia and said:

Let me just show your viewers . . . This shows 78 per cent of the land mass of Australiaâcoloured brown on the map. Now, the Labor Party and the Democrats are effectively saying that the Aboriginal people of Australia should have the potential right of veto over further development of 78 per cent of the land mass of Australia.
He then told the 7.30 Report viewers:
Now that is a very simple message. I think the Australian people will understand that message.

It was a very simple message, delivered via a map coloured brown. He was saying to the community that if we are not careful the blacks will take over the place. It was almost identicalâand just as misleadingâto the crude but effective campaign run by the Western Australian Chamber of Mines in the 1980s. The only difference is that their map was black, not brown.

And now the Prime Minister has turned his hand to demonising the wharfies. He has decided to be a more sophisticated person in his approach to this matter. First, he had to create the image. How was this achieved? Through his ministers he appointed Liberal pollster Mark Textor, the principal of Australasian Research Services. Mr Textor, it should be remembered, is closely associated with the technique of push polling. This first appeared on the Australian political landscape in the 1994 Northern Territory Election. Voters were asked if they would change their vote if they knew the following facts. They were then told that Territory Labor planned to introduce two sets of lawsâone for blacks and another for whites. The Country-Liberal Party employed Mr Textor in the lead up to that election as a polling adviser. The Liberal Party also employed the same technique in the lead up to the Federal by-election for the seat of Canberra. Mr Textor was the pollster for the Liberal Party for the 1996 election campaign.

Last year Mr Howard, Mr Reith and Mr Sharp commissioned Mr Textor to attack not their political opponents but an industrial union. The work was channelled through the ACIL consultancy. Mr Textor then organised a number of focus groups. He showed them parts of a 60 Minutes program and other material designed to colour their view, including edited `highlights' of an address by the Secretary of the ACTU, Bill Kelty. He was paid over $40,000 for his trouble.

Despite his best efforts the waterfront and wharfies were not considered to be so-called `top the mind' issues. There was strong concern about waterfront efficiency, international competitiveness and any hindrances to exports. The Textor research was then provided to a second consultantâlong time Liberal Party election strategist, Jonathon Gaul. The Gaul plan was to use the Textor research to paint the wharfies as the privileged eliteâ$100,000 for 14 hours a week and then they all nick off anyway. That is the sort of line we have been hearing from this government and that is the line that was created by Jonathon Gaul.

As with the Asians in 1988, the Aborigines and the Wik message, it was both simple and divisive. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would know that the average wharfie is like any other Australian worker. He has to work long hours to make ends meet. He has a family to support. And in many cases he does achieve world's best practice in his workplace. At the port of Burnie in my state, Tasmania, the waterside workers achieved an average rate, I believe, of 33 containers per hour in the week before they were dismissed. In the state of Queensland, your state, Madam Acting Deputy President, Townsville is a port of hard working and highly productive workers. What did the Prime Minister say of their fate? The Prime Minister was interviewed on A Current Affair two days after Chris Corrigan implemented what the government thought was the final part of its grand plan to smash the MUA. He was asked about workers in ports like Burnie and Townsville and why they were sacked along with their colleagues in Sydney and Melbourne. He said:
They are all part of the one union.
Guilty by association.

This country has changed dramatically under the leadership of John Howard. There is now mistrust in the community. There is now a high level of insecurity about what the future might bring. Mr Howard has achieved all of this in just over two years. His is already a remarkable record. I, together with many Australians, hope the legacy of this Prime Minister, as Prime Minister, is a short one.

The Senate would recall that the last time Mr Howard lost his job he mocked the suggestion of a possible return by claiming that that would amount to Lazarus with a triple bypass. We now know that we have Lazarus with a triple bypass as our Prime Minister. The question that must be answered and will be answered, and in the hearts of many Australians has already been answered, is: has John Howard got the ticker for the job that he now has? The facts show that he has not.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to talk on a matter of public interest affecting my state of Queensland that has considerable relevance to the outcome of the state election. I am referring to the shredding of the Heiner inquiry documents and further evidence that has come to light and been prominently featured in the media in recent days. All senators know that this is a matter that I have spoken on on quite a number of occasions. Indeed, I referred the matter of whether or not the Criminal Justice Commission may have given false and misleading evidence to the Senate select committee into unresolved whistleblower cases in 1995 to the Senate Privileges Committee on 5 December 1997 for further examination. In making this speech, I am not showing any disrespect to the deliberations of the Privileges Committee, but there is fresh disturbing evidence relating to the shredding that I believe this chamber and certainly the people of Queensland ought to be aware of and fully comprehend its significance.

speech.para: Before I do that, I want to put on the public record something that has personally disturbed me ever since the unresolved whistleblower cases committee tabled its report in October 1995. In that report we described the shredding as `an exercise in poor judgement'. I have given that view very careful consideration ever since and I now wish to disassociate myself from that description and suggest that it was quite inadequate. In my opinion, in light of the facts and the emerging evidence, it was a very soft political view that can no longer stand. I believe that we sent our Australian community a bad signal by not facing the cold, hard facts that a so-called desirable, political objective may not always be lawful. That precise scenario is what the Howard government and Patricks may be facing in the courts in respect of the unacceptable sudden sacking of 1,400 MUA members supposedly to achieve a more efficient waterfront. I remind the Senate that Justice Wilcox said in the appeal court ruling that noble objectives cannot be achieved by ignoble means.

It has been argued that the shredding was done to protect people from suing each other over evidence given to the Heiner inquiry because of the way it was established. At first glance this looks fair enough, but standing between that objective was the lawful right of citizens to access those public records or, at the very least, to test that right in court through judicial interpretation of the relevant statute. Indeed, the known would-be litigant, Mr Peter Coyne, and his solicitor were deceived by the Crown into believing that the evidence was secure while, behind the screen of expectation that the Crown would act with the utmost probity, the documents were shredded to stop their use in that foreshadowed litigation. It is my view now that we should have taken greater consideration of the views expressed by now High Court Justice Ian Callinan QC, who represented Mr Lindeberg, that arguably the decision to shred the records seriously breached the criminal law.

In moving my motion to have the Lindeberg matter referred again to the Privileges Committee, I indicated that it appeared that what was shredded was evidence of possible child abuse. My worst fears appear to have been realised by the most extraordinary of circumstances. I refer to recent headlines in the Courier-Mail of 25 May 1998 that former Queensland Police Commissioner Noel Newnham, a man for whom I have the greatest respect, carried out a three-day investigation for Mr Lindeberg into what was told to Mr Heiner. I remind the Senate that the current opposition leader, Mr Peter Beattie, has described the Heiner inquiry as `a spat between public servants' in an attempt, I guess, to downplay its importance.

However, in his inquiry Mr Newnham found that Mr Heiner was given evidence of possible serious child abuse of detainees. He found that children as young as 10 and 12 had been handcuffed to water grates in the open air all night, with one child, who was told that snakes came out of the grate, being found the next morning with his blanket stuffed down the grate because of his fear. Others, it is alleged, were handcuffed to beds for extended periods. It is also alleged that there was inappropriate use of suppressant drugs for other than medical reasons, and that there was also psychological and physical abuse.

I want to add of course that I am not apportioning blame to anyone. That needs to be done by a proper investigation. I am indicating, however, that very serious evidence of possible abuse was given to Mr Heiner, and it was shredded. Undoubtedly, anyone accused had a right to clear their names, but the electorate also has a right to know what was going on behind those closed walls. The shredding prevented this.
Mr Newnham points out in his report that the use of excessive or unnecessary force against people in lawful custody amounts to criminal assault. He says:
In the case of minors such assaults by custodial officials, directly or indirectly, must always be regarded as extremely serious.
He further says:
. . . Australia has international treaty obligations regarding the treatment of people in custody and of children. It appears plain that officials disregarded some of those obligations.

He also said that it was an absurd notion to suggest that the Crown had to shred these documents to prevent people suing each other. I happen to agree with Mr Newnham. It is absurd to suggest that the Crown cannot handle documents containing such evidence and that its only remedy was to destroy them.

This fresh evidence obviously opens up very serious questions that, I suggest, the Privileges Committee may not be able to ignore, especially in the light of other revelations involving the CJC's handling of this matter. Mr Newnham suggests that it is quite inconceivable that the Goss government would have been unaware of these allegations when deciding what to do with the Heiner documents.

But it does not stop there. It turns out that a youth worker who gave evidence to Mr Heiner on these matters has been in contact with the CJC since 1994 by phoneâand as late as October 1997 in writingâwanting the CJC to investigate these matters. The CJC has dismissed his concerns, the same complaints it now wants to investigate following the Courier-Mail's pressure and the intervention of Mr Newnham. All of a sudden the CJC now has an interest in the matter. The CJC never told the Senate of these contacts, leaving us to believe that all of the Heiner witnesses were relieved to see the so-called defamatory evidence destroyed. I believe that is gross deception on the part of the CJC.

On Monday, 25 May 1998, the CJC announced that it was going to investigate these 1989-1990 complaints, after considerable media uproar. It is quite inappropriate for the CJC to come within cooee of this matter. It cannot assure anyone of its impartiality. The fact that the CJC did not see any ethical or conflict of interest barriers to its taking on the task is something of even greater concern to me, and merely confirms that the CJC has lost its plot.

I believe that the CJC is an institution which must remain in the state of Queensland. It is critical that it do so. But it is a patient that is sick. It needs to take its medicine, it needs to get well and then perhaps it can get on with the job. The problem I have is that the CJC has not told the public about its glaring ethical impediment to its involvement now and that its deception is of the highest order. It is impossible to dissociate the shredding from what was actually shredded. They are both sides of the same coin.

We have already seen what happens to other people who go to the CJC on matters associated with the Heiner inquiry, and now it is inviting more public servants to face potentially the same fate. We have seen Mr Lindeberg disgracefully ridiculed in public by the CJC over his efforts to see the truth emerge. I hold a genuine fear for other people who might believe that the CJC comes to this matter with clean hands for I believe they could suffer the same fate as Mr Lindeberg. I am sorry to have to say that, but the CJC's credentials in relation to the shredding and anything to do with the Heiner inquiry are very much in doubt.

Mr Lindeberg made it quite plain in evidence to the Senate inquiry that he views the CJC's handling of his allegations as biased and contrived to obstruct the truth coming out. Mr Lindeberg's serious assertions, in my view, should be heard by the new Parliamentary Commissioner for the CJC, Ms Julie Dick SC, as soon as possible.

When this new evidence emerged in the Courier-Mail, the Queensland Premier, Mr Borbidge, publicly suggested that barristers Messrs Morris QC and Howard had looked at the Newnham revelations. That is quite untrue. Mr Morris QC has also dissociated himself from the Premier's comments. I must say that either the Premier was being unacceptably dismissive of them or he is so misinformed as to be out of his depth on this matterâas he is on many matters, I might addâand that is very sad indeed. The Premier further suggested that the Newnham revelations had gone to the Queensland Director of Public Prosecutions. That also is untrue.

As for Mr Beattie, he wants the CJC to look into the matter. I am afraid that is a joke, and a sick one at that. The CJC is so compromised in this affair that any investigation into the shredding and related matters, including the fresh revelations, must include the CJC's handling of the Lindeberg allegations.

Finally, the scale of the corrupt tentacles associated with the shredding is so vast and so serious that it warrants the appointment of a special prosecutor who can take and hear evidence in public under oath and prosecute where necessary. Really we can have nothing less. The system itself is on trial. This matter touches the office of Governor in Council; the office of Cabinet; the office of Crown Law; the FOI Commissioner; the Queensland audit office; the Queensland police; the CJC; senior public servants, retired and serving; a trade union; and goes as far as a credit union. The time to act is long past. Justice has been delayed for too long for people like Mr Lindeberg. The Australian Democrats have continued to be the only political avenue for Mr Lindeberg to pursue justice in this matter. Both of the major parties have failed Queensland and Mr Lindeberg, and that failure continues to this day.

If we condone the shredding and ignore these recent revelations by further inaction, dithering and dodging, it will show that we have lost the plot about what a decent society means. We will have reduced ourselves to a state of ridicule and anarchy. This is above party politics. The Australian Democrats demand action to get to the truth of this matter immediately and in full.

talk.start.para: âIf ever proof were needed of just how strong a hold the union movement has over the Labor Party, one need look no further than the debacle over the attempted privatisation of the NSW electricity industry. This is a matter of public importance that I will address in this debate.

speech.para: The issues involved are immense. The Carr government claims the New South Wales industry is worth $22 billion. However, the more realistic figure puts its value at $28 billion. This valuation is more realistic because it uses current Victorian sell-off prices which have been adjusted for interest rate declines. In blunt terms, this puts the industry's worth at between 15 and 20 per cent of the state's GDP.

At present NSW has crippling debt of nearly $20 billion. That would be wiped out and the resultant interest savings of $720 million a year would go to schools, hospitals, police and other necessary services. And a report by the Australian Council for Infrastructure Development released only weeks ago says privatisation of the power industry will create about 167,000 jobs. The study, prepared by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research, also points to a 10 per cent cost saving from privatisation.

The arguments for full privatisation are therefore compelling. The reality is that, if the taxpayers of New South Wales knew how much they had at risk in the New South Wales electricity industry, there would be mass demonstrations calling for its privatisation.

All of this must also be looked at in the context of the tax regime in New South Wales. Since Bob Carr came to power in 1995, the state has gone from having the lowest tax growth rate to becoming the highest taxed state in Australia. Tax revenue has risen by $2Â½ billion in just three years. There have been 13 tax increases, and they include three new taxesâone of which is the iniquitous land tax on people living in their own homesâthat have been imposed on the people of New South Wales.

During the Carr years, government expenditure has risen unaccountably by more than 20 per cent. On top of this, Bob Carr is looking to a piecemeal sale of the power industry. Even that stalwart of the Labor Party, Graham Richardson, recognises the need to privatise the whole industry. Writing in the Bulletin recently, he said the coalition would go into the next election promising to sell off the power industry. Here I quote Mr Richardson:

This will enable Peter Collins, the New South Wales leader of the Opposition, to promise substantially lower electricity prices for businesses and households. He will also have the luxury of deciding how to lavish upon the electorate something like $20 billion which he will reap from carrying out the privatisation policy already espoused by Carr. There is now a competitive market for electricity in Australia and by corporatising the various entities in electricity generation and provision, New South Wales businesses are paying only 40 per cent of what they paid for electricity when Labor came to office three years ago.

This makes those entities tremendously attractive to private buyers who would vie with privately owned competitors in Victoria. They will pay top dollar and Peter Collins will promise to retire state debt, fix the schools, fix the hospitals, fix the trains, fix the buses and put police back on the streets. Against all this, Bob Carr will offer his best wishes and his hopes that this party might one day reconsider its position.

How humiliating for Mr Carr to have a Labor Party heavyweight publicly acknowledge the Premier's impotence at the hands of the unions over plans to privatise the $28 billion power industry. Although he claims his gover nment is committed to a full privatisation, the latest move from his bunker this month was a half-baked plan for partial privatisation of the New South Wales electricity industry, only, of course, if his union mates agreed to it.

Under this latest proposal only the power generators would be privatised and the electricity distribution and retail companies would remain under public ownership. But how did Mr Carr arrive at this bifurcated approach? The answer is he was trying to appease his union mates, those same union mates who constantly rebuff him and put at risk huge sums of money which would help the people of New South Wales by retiring state debt and freeing up capital for infrastructure and social projects.

The latest round of privatisation talks have highlighted the power two right wing unionsâthe Municipal Employees Union and the Electricity Trades Unionâhave over the New South Wales Labor government. The plan to sell off only the three generators for $10 billion is tailor made for the right wing unions as most of their members are in the six distribution companies. What a surprise!

The New South Wales government has sought to sell off the power industry and both right and left wing unions have bluntly told Mr Carr they will not let that happen. What right they think they have to take such a position against the public interest beggars belief.

Recently, the left wing Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union broke off talks with the Carr government and walked out of meetings. They took their bat and ball and refused to play, and Mr Carr was powerless to do a thing about it. Not surprisingly, many CFMEU members are employed at the three generators. Mr Carr is unashamedly playing union politics with one of the state's great assets, its power industry.

What all this means is that New South Wales is suffering accelerating losses through the Labor Party's stubborn refusal to acknowledge the inevitability of a privatised power industry throughout the area covered by the interconnected electricity grid. A partial privatisation is a nonsense and simply will not work. However, under a New South Wales coalition government there will not be this nonsense as the coalition has stated clearly and often that it will sell the power industry as a whole.

One of the primary reasons for the privatisation of the New South Wales electricity industry is to provide a capital boost for the state, as well as lower prices for consumers. The capital boost of more than $20 billion will help to retire debt and rebuild the state's economy with infrastructure projects that will also create jobs.

The real benefit is that in retiring debt, the privatisation of the electricity industry will save the New South Wales government, and therefore the people of New South Wales, $720 million in interest payments each year. That $720 million will enable the New South Wales Liberal government to make significant and lasting gains for the people of New South Wales. It will leave the state almost entirely free of debt. That means it will leave a state which future generations can enjoy without crippling taxes and other charges now being imposed upon them to pay the interest debt racked up due to years of Labor mismanagement.

So what is it that the unions object to and which tie Bob Carr's hands? The unions have thrown up the usual arguments of possible job losses and erosion of conditions as a result of the sale. Some opposition to any sale rests purely, no doubt, on so-called ideological grounds, but both objections miss the whole point. Electricity supply and generation is now a competitive business, and it will become more so.

If the New South Wales electricity generation industry is to remain competitive in the current deregulated market, it will need a substantial injection of funds to ensure it is in the race with other states. No government can really justify such an injection of taxpayers' funds and this, in itself, highlights the inevitability of privatisation.

It was the coalition government under former premiers Nick Greiner and John Fahey that first realised this and stepped in to begin the process by putting electricity transmission on a commercial footing. But this has stalled because of the Carr government's impotence.

What the next coalition government will do is to privatise because New South Wales needs the money and it makes good business sense to do so. Frankly, New South Wales has come to a dead end in terms of raising new taxes, and the sale of non-core assets is the rational solution to this revenue crunch.

Also, there is no economic justification for the government to run non-core assets. There are very few utilities or services that need to be run by the government to operate efficiently and fairly and to deliver an essential service.

The notion that governments should own utilities is largely a hangover from the now defunct theory of natural monopolies. This concept refers to an industry in which technological imperatives preclude competition from smaller players or new entrants. Given that only one player could gain sufficient scale in any one market, it was thought then desirable that that player be owned by the government, which could be trusted not to exploit its position.

This is all lost on those in the Labor Party who still have their head in the sand. They fail to realise that the privatisation of the electricity industry will create a number of utilities providing competition and better service for consumers. In economic terms it makes absolutely no sense to have billions of dollars of taxpayers' money tied up in an industry that has become highly competitive since it was opened up in May last year. The fact is that the government has no say in the price of electricity, which is set by market forces. In New South Wales, the publicly owned generators and distributors compete against each other and interstate rivals to see who can deliver the cheapest power. What is happening is that, because it will not or cannot sell these businesses, the New South Wales government is unlikely to see a meaningful dividend from this industry for several years. So, while the government's dividend income from ownership diminishes, it is at risk of losing billions of dollars of shareholder value.

In a report published in Company Director, accountancy group KPMG writes that there is likely to be a large field of bidders, given the Victorian and other recent electricity sector sales. But it warns that there are unique risks, and questions how long the current situation of oversupply is sustainable in the market. In other words, the time to act is sooner rather than later. This is the point of my speech today. This is highlighted by the recent United Energy float in Victoria, which closed three times oversubscribed. Significantly, the blueprint for the United Energy privatisation closely resembles that outlined by consultants Deutsche Morgan Grenfell to the committee of inquiry last year into the sale of New South Wales power assets. The Carr government could have and should have acted then.

Separately, a KPMG analyst said that the longer the government waited to sell the power industry, the greater the risks involved as the assets depreciated, and international interest could weaken. He said also that the longer the government waited, the greater the drain on the state's economy through interest payments on unpaid debt.

What the unions refuse to realise is that the window of opportunity to sell power utilities at huge prices is limited. One reason for the high prices being commanded at present is that there is intense overseas interest in the electricity industry. Adding to their high value are low interest rates and high market valuations. The shareholders are benefiting. For instance, AGL, which now owns Victoria's Solaris distributor, has seen its share price surge from $8 to $12.65 in just six months. That is a price-earning multiple change from 3.7 times to 21.7. Utility stocks are on a roll across the share market, trading at a valuation multiple above ordinary industrial stocks.

But this will not last forever. When the New South Wales coalition government is elected in March 1999, as it surely will be, one of its first priorities will be to deliver to the people of New South Wales the benefits from a full privatisation of the electricity industry. It will also enable the people of New South Wales to share in the bonanza by becoming shareholders in utilities. All that is being denied to them now, during this twilight period when the unions have decided to refuse their neighbours and their families the benefits to be had. Not even Mr Carr can manage to backflip on this one, and present and future generations of people in New South Wales will only continue to be adversely affected.

talk.start.para: âIn Sleepers, Wake! , the Hon. Barry Jones, MP, a former Labor minister for science and technology, wrote that capital, land and labour, the three factors of production, have been joined by a fourth: knowledge. Information and knowledge are the empowering tools of today's society but, as my colleague puts it: is this information a free good? If so, what levels of responsibility should government take in providing an accessible information superhighway as opposed to a tollway? As knowledge and information are integral factors in production, control over the carriers of information becomes increasingly paramount to our future. If information is a right, then access to the information highway should be freely available and affordable to everybody.

speech.para: By contrast, there are those, like this government, that believe information is a private or commercial commodity that should be sold or licensed. Whilst there are sectors that can legitimately apply an added value in the transmission, it can be said that what we are dealing with here is something that is a resource to this country as opposed to a consumer commodity. By ceding control to the corporate sector the government is, in effect, selling off one of the means by which all Australians can enter and participate in the electronic society.

Fair and equitable participation in this new paradigm of communications and information sharing is something that Labor holds true to its philosophies and principles, but something that remains very distant from the philosophies being espoused by the government. As the Howard government begins the process of selling off the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, it is fundamentally important that we assess information technologies not only to find out where they are taking us but also to analyse who is being left behind.

One of the largest groups marginalised in the IT revolution and changes to the information and communication paradigm are rural and remote Australians. If you live off the main road then you are literally out of sight and out of mind of this government. Likewise, the information superhighway is bypassing anyone not connected to the main road. Rural people know only too well what it is to be forgotten. The decline in rural banking services is just one example. One in three major bank branches in rural areas closed between 1993 and 1996, rendering 600 rural communities without access to proper financial institutions.

Rural residents do not have the same access to support structures that metropolitan citizens enjoy. They must survive without the networks that underpin city life. If you live on a remote or distant property you do not have the same sort of access to support or help to manage your computer's file management problem or if your hard drive crashes. There generally are no local training courses, localised help desks or even computer stores that can offer sales and post-purchase service that the rest of us can access quite freely.

Unfortunately, it is not just rural residents who are unable to ride the superhighway. Older Australians, Australians with a socioeconomic disadvantage and, in particular, Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders are in a similar boat. Statistically, we know, as a result of an ABS survey late last year, that these factors are significant in explaining the inequities to access to the new information technologies. About 60 per cent of Australians on rural and remote settlements are Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, and their telecommunication needs are not being addressed.

I recently came across a report that reaffirmed that rural Australians need a world-class telephone system. But they also need world-class television, radio, fax and e-mail services and a quality postal service just to remain a part of society, to have current and relevant connections with society. I know many rural people will laugh at this, but many of them are struggling because they are still struggling just to have a standard telecommunications or telephone service. E-mail and the Internet are pipedreams at the moment. Yet the Internet and enhanced information services can deliver essential information about their primary industry, the weather reports, legal services, the stock market and new product and marketing opportunities.

With the recent developments in electronic commerce, being on-line means overcoming the lack of commercial and retail services that rural communities and small towns cannot offer. This in turn introduces a whole range of social challenges and regional economic issues that will have to be confronted. To ignore the ramifications of some of these changes in this context is certainly at the government's peril. The principle goal of any government should be to ensure that rural consumers and rural citizens have the same telecommunications and information services as city residents.

One of the more interesting developments in this area is the current pricing regimes between the carriers providing Internet services to rural areas compared to metropolitan areas. I watched with interest the pricing disadvantage that currently exists between the two groups in this country, and relate it back to how those rural people are, on the one hand, being encouraged quite stridently by government to participate in this new on-line revolution but, at the same time, the government is choosing to ignore the means that they have at their fingertips to ensure price equity and access equity to the services.

We often hear too from this government about its commitment to small business. The recent electronic commerce summit here in Canberra highlighted access issues for small business, particularly those in rural and regional areas. The pricing inequities that currently exist between the two metropolitan areas and the rural areas show that Telstra at that time provided a significant disadvantage to rural consumers. I note with interest in yesterday's Australian that Telstra's Internet product, Big Pond, has joined the rush to provide flat rate Internet access. This is quite an intriguing development, given that the major carriers and certainly the major providers of ISPs moved away from flat rate Internet access quite early on in the development of that market on the basis that industry analysts and their own economics in providing that service demonstrated that that was unviable in the long term.

So what do we see now? We see, once again, competition perhaps playing a role in the provision of these flat rate services, given that another provider of Internet services, OzEmail, instituted the same regime just recently. What we have in two major metropolitan areas is a response from Telstra to a move by OzEmail to instigate, once again, a flat rate Internet access pricing package. What we do not see is a rural centre being offered the same service or the same pricing regime. What we do not see are those non-competitive areas in this country getting offered a cut-price or discount regime or access to the Internet.

What we do see are the metropolitan areas that are well serviced, that have a profit margin that is worth it for these private companies to actually pursue market share and to extract a profit from, being the sole beneficiaries of the competitive pressures that are existing. What is happening is that rural and remote Australians do not even get subjected to the competitive pressures that could lower the costs that are currently being imposed on them for Internet access.

I also note with interest media speculation on this specific area, where it talks about the contemplation by the government of enhancing the regulatory regime to actually ensure that somehow the services are maintained to rural and remote Australia. This comes back to quite a powerful contradiction that is underpinning or, I suppose, upstaging to a large degree the government's whole rhetoric about their move to full privatisation of the carrier Telstra.

The government cannot guarantee the delivery of adequate services, either on the Internet or even in telecommunications generally, to rural and regional Australia without enhancing the regulatory framework to enforce it. Why? Competitive pressures do not exist where there is no profit to be made out of a given market. Because Australia is such a big place, there are several areas in this country which will never make money on behalf of a carrier, an Internet service provider or anybody else.

How will the government put pressure on the various Internet service providers, for example, to lower their costs for those regional subscribers? How will they ensure that OzEmail, Big Pond or regional ISPs actually want to compete in rural and remote communities? The fundamental flaw in the government's plan is that that will not happen. The only way it can deliver a base level of service is to regulate and to provide for compliance measures and, hopefully, penalties that will stick.

To go back to the earlier points I made about inequities between rural communities and metropolitan communities, and the value of knowledge and information in our society: we have a grave situation emerging where the information poor and the information rich will be divided, not just along socioeconomic lines, but along geographical lines as well. At a time when we on this side of the chamber are so mindful of these widening disparities, these social inequities, we have a government that consistently ignores the structural ramifications of its policies in relation to privatisation and to playing with the regulatory structures in regard to competition policy.

All of these arguments lead to a fairly straightforward message. The existence of information rich and information poor, and the widening gap between the two, is not an argument in itself against the privatisation of public assets. But the implications of that policy extend far beyond economic considerations and public and private revenues. They extend far beyond a comparative benefit to shareholders or potential shareholders, and the public interest. What they go to is how we will cohesively, as a society, progress and developâhow we will cohesively take advantage of the information revolution, this new paradigm that we are already embracing but that many Australians have no opportunity to participate in.

To deal with these issues in isolation is to deliver the largest proportion of Australians to exclusion from these developments and changes. This, obviously, is an act of gross negligence on the part of this government. We have seen so many examples of efforts on their part to demonstrate to the Australian community that in some way they have tapped into the information revolution.

We saw a very belated establishment of the National Office of Information Economy. It is now struggling to play catch-up with critical issues that have been affecting other economies in other countries for a number of years. We see a conference on electronic commerce come over two years into the government's term. Was it preceded by a conference on the social implications of this information revolution? Was it preceded by a conference on just what it meant to be excluded from the information revolution? No, straight to the business aspect, straight to the economic angle.
Unless this government puts people first in its consideration of information technology matters, these inequities will only increase. It is an imperative. (Time expired)

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.57 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Ellison, Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is it not the case that job brokers like Employment National, Drake, Mission Australia and the Salvation Army have no legal and contractual obligations to help find a job for those not on benefits? Is it not also correct that for the middle-aged unemployed the best thing is to get them job help immediately?

question.para: Can the minister confirm that, under the government's new system, if you are middle-aged and married, you will be denied immediate guaranteed free employment services and forced to the back of the unemployment queue? Is the minister aware that there are 400,000-plus unemployed Australians who are now being forced to the back of the queue by the new job network?

talk.start.para: âOf course, that is not true. We have provided more opportunities for job seekers and some three-quarters of those organisations which successfully tendered for thisâand there were 310 organisationsâwere involved in existing programs in relation to job search and looking after people who are looking for work. Over half involved case management and skillshare people and 50 per cent were involved in dealing with the more disadvantaged section of the job seeking population.

answer.para: That means that, out of the 310 organisations, a good percentage of those people who will help people look for work have had experience in dealing with disadvantaged people. In that I include indigenous people, migrants and those people who are older. When Senator Sherry looks at those figures, he can rest assured that there are people in the job network system who are experienced in dealing with this sector of the market.

We have contracted with these providers to provide jobs for the allowees, that is, those people who are eligible job seekers. They get paid when they find those people work. That is part of the job network system. It has also brought into the system experienced people to assist those others whom Senator Sherry has mentioned, and these people have that experience. Fifty per cent of these people have experience in dealing with disadvantaged people, and I include in that those people who have some sort of disadvantageâsuch as those who have English as their second language, migrants, indigenous people and the older cohort.

talk.start.para: âYesterday in the other place the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Evans, sought to evadeâI am sorry, my question is actually addressed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justiceâ
âI think she had a rough idea.

âI am sure she did, the moment I mentioned the first line. Yesterday in the other place the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Evans, sought to evade responsibility for issuing Mr Skase with a new 10-year passport by asserting that he had no discretion to refuse its issue. Senator Bolkus then claimed that Mr Skase's new 10-year passport had been of absolutely no use as it had no travel stamps or visas in it. Could the previous government have stopped Mr Skase from getting a new 10-year passport and would Mr Skase's new 10-year passport have been of any use to him at all?

âI thank Senator Knowles for her question. Yes, the previous government could have stopped Mr Skase getting a new 10-year passport, and yes, a new 10-year passport would have been of use to Mr Skase.

answer.para: The former Senator Evans, now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, had four clear options; four discretions to stop Skase getting a brand new passport valid until the year 2003. He could have firstly thought about it for longer than two working days. He could have given it the attention it deserved.

Secondly, he could have refused to issue a passport under section 7D of the Passports Act. Thirdly, he could have cancelled any passport under section 8(1) of the same act and, fourthly, he could have issued a new passport, a very short-term one, say for three months, or even a one-way travel document back to Australia.

Let me turn to the first issue. There is no requirement to issue a new passport in a couple of working days. The minister could have waited a couple of months and considered the matter properly. This was a sensitive matter. A passport alert had been issued. Thousands of Australians had lost their money and a minister is entitledâindeed, obligatedâto give the matter proper consideration. Mr Evans admitted that the former government was trying to get arrest warrants issued which would have given one ground for refusing the new passport. Mr Evans could have and should have given the matter better consideration.

Secondly, former Senator Evans and Senator Bolkus have been out there claiming that section 7 of the Passports Act in effect only allows a minister to refuse a passport if a warrant has been issued for the arrest of the applicant. Now, that is just not true. They failed to mention section 7D of the Passports Act. Senator Bolkus failed to distribute section 7D to the media, which entitles a minister to refuse to issue a passport if somebody already has a valid one, unless there are special reasons.

Mr Skase had a valid passport on which he could have travelled back to Australia, but of course Mr Skase told everybody he was too sick to travel. What were the special reasons that Mr Evans and his department accepted as being good and proper reasons to give a new 10-year passport to Mr Skase?

Thirdly, section 8 of the Passports Act gives the minister a very broad general discretion to cancel a passport. Mr Downer cancelled Mr Skase's passport. Why didn't Mr Evans do the same? Fourthly, Mr Evans could have issued a limited short-term passport for, say, four months and by that time possibly the arrest warrants that he was seeking to have issued would have been issued.

Here we have Mr Evans claiming that he had no choice and that he was just the innocent minister, when in fact he had four options not to give Skase a brand new 10-year passport. Mr Evans was the minister, and he is clearly culpable.

Of course a passport is of use to someone. A valid passport can be used to travel to countries where a visa is not required. So a stamp does not need to be put in it. But you need to show that you are an Australian citizen so you do not need a stamp. You can use it to cash travellers cheques to buy the necessities of life, like a wheelchair or an oxygen mask or some golf clubs. You can use it to open bank accounts in Switzerland, where you store all the money that you perhaps have taken out of Australia. You can use it to rent expensive properties. A passport has a whole range of usesâ

talk.start.para: âHow did he get to Switzerland?

âSenator Bolkus is clearly unaware of the uses of a passport. That is why he does not care that Labor gave Mr Skase a brand spanking new 10-year passport. It is an absolute disgrace. The passport could be used to identify yourself to collect cargoâ(Time expired)

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. If the minister has time I would like to know what some of the other uses of the passport are that Senator Bolkus does not obviously realise. Also, given your answer, Minister, was Senator Bolkus's explanationâthat Labor would have cancelled the passport if someone had suggested it to themâa reasonable defence?

âI read with deep regret Senator Bolkus's press release yesterday, when he indicated that law enforcement authorities had never suggested the cancellation, and if they had, he saidâlet me read it to you:

answer.para: If they had ever suggested to us that cancelling his passport was the best way to proceed then we would have acted on their advice immediately.

What does that say? It says, `We didn't have any ideas in our own heads as the government.' That is what it says. They had no ideas. Nothing has changed there. Then he says that if they had thought about it, and someone had suggested it, they would have acted without consideration. They would not have considered the advice; they would have done it immediately. How does that contrast with what Senator Bolkus said in the past? Listen to this. This is Senator Bolkus:
And what really grates with me is that the Prime Minister is basically making the bureaucrats take the rap for a decision that his own minister could very well have taken.
Senator Bolkus knows that this is the decision that Mr Evans could have and should have taken and did not, and now he is trying to say that the bureaucrats did not suggest it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOrder! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Islamic Republic of Pakistan, led by the Chairman of the Senate, Senator Wasim Sajjad. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. I trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I would propose to invite the Chairman to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.
âHear, hear!

para.inline: Senator Wasim Sajjad was seated accordingly.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Resources and Energy: Farm Assistance Package

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Given that the minister was not able to answer my question yesterday regarding the property holdings of Kiskin LtdâI suppose it is difficult to keep track of such wealthâI ask: can the minister confirm that some or all of the property holdings of his Kiskin company have direct or indirect links with the minister's portfolio responsibilities for coal? Specifically, can he confirm that Kiskin owns the Hillview cattle property, and can he confirm that this property contains significant reserves of coal deposits? When will the minister acknowledge that these very real and substantial conflicts of interest continue to damage the credibility of the government and the Prime Minister?
âSenator Faulkner kicks off these questions with statements that are incorrect. I do not have a company called Kiskin, never have had a company called Kiskin. As has been disclosedâ
âIs it your family trust?

âthe family trust, which has been legally moved across to the family where it operated for about the last two or three years or more, had an interest in that of two per cent. Part of that process was that Kiskin, which was really owned by the four major shareholders of the company, had its assets outside coalmining leases. This included a range of things, like the housing I mentioned yesterday. It also in the processâI think the time was about 1993âacquired a cattle property.
âWhat about Kiskin unit trusts?
âWhat are you taking about, you galah?

answer.para: It acquired a cattle property, and it operated as a cattle property. Since the time that I resigned as Chairman of QCMM I have no knowledge whatsoever of the ongoing ownershipâof what Kiskin owns or what it does not own.

talk.start.para: âI ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Given that the Minister for Resources yesterday admitted that he owned through Kiskin a number of residential properties used to house workers and contractors in his own coal mine, namely Jellinbah, is that the real reason that the minister did not fully declare his property holdings through Kiskin? When can the parliament, Minister, expect a full and truthful disclosure of all your conflicts of interest, shares and property? When will the minister do the right thing by his colleagues and by his mate the Prime Minister and resign?

âWe have Senator Faulkner regurgitating this over and over again. There has been no conflict of interest. You have shown no conflict of interest, and no potential for the conflict of interest. Here you are asking me to run out individual properties. I suppose you want to know the names of the people who live in the houses. The actual assets themselves could well have been held by QCMM. If they were, you are saying you want nominated what piece of machinery. I am sure that pieces of machinery up there would be worth more than a house. This is just rubbish stuff coming again from Senator Faulkner. Full disclosure has been made. There has been no conflict of interest. As I said to Senator Robert Ray yesterday, you are flogging a dead horse. Full disclosure has been made.

âMy question is also to the Minister for Resources and Energy but, by contrast, it is actually about an issue of national significance. I ask the minister whether he is aware that the Australian gold industry, particularly in Western Australia and Queensland, is under significant pressure as a result of two factors, one of which is the falling gold price and the other is the current impasse in the Senate in relation to native title. I ask the minister: what is the effect of native title on the gold industry, particularly on jobs and investment?

âI am pleased to report that my colleague Senator Crane and I had a meeting yesterday with the high level working group on gold which came out of a very successful gold round table held earlier this year. The meeting was once again an opportunity to speak frankly about the issues confronting the gold industry at this time and develop joint strategies to address these issues. The meeting heard of the gold low price and some uncertainty, particularly in respect of Korea, which is placing substantial pressure on exploration and new supply.

answer.para: There was also general acknowledgment of the need for targeted consultation on a number of key issues. By far the most significant issue raised was the effect of native title and their palpable anger with the Labor Party. For example, in Western Australia the average time now taken for the grant of a mining lease is more than double that of 1994-95 and many of the applications have now been outstanding for more than two years. Delays in granting exploration titles are being experienced across the whole country, particularly Queensland, Western Australia and parts of New South Wales. They place an enormous burden on the nation. They increase costs to industry, costs to government and administration, and costs arising from court actions. The bottom line is they cost jobs. Again, in Western Australia over 4,000 mining lease applications cannot be granted because they are held up in the native title process, while in Queensland there are 700 applications for exploration permits and over 400 applications for mining titles currently held up as a result of the Native Title Act and the Wik decision. Yet, the Labor Party continues to frustrate the government's sensible and fair proposals for amendments to the Native Title Act. This has not gone un-noticed in the community. Writing in the latest annual report, Mr Ryan, the President of the Association of Mining and Exploration Companiesâwhich, I might remind the Senate, represents the battlers in the industryâmade a statement which sena tors will want to listen to, particular the Western Australians. He said:
The federal Labor opposition has lost its way on native title and has been remarkably recalcitrant in addressing the nation's interests, rather than matters of ideology and short-term political gain.

Labor is also speaking with forked tongue. It cannot be trusted. Last year, Senator Crane and I went to Kalgoorlie, but just before we arrived there, guess who was there? Mr Beazley and Mr Smith were there and do you know what they told the miners? They said they could relax because they were going to support our native title amendments. That is what the miners told us. What hypocrisy. They either misled the miners or they were rolled by the left, Senator Faulkner.

Madam President, do you know what they have done in Queensland because there is a state election on? They have told their shadow ministers that any statements on native title will have to be cleared through Wayne Swan. The Labor Party is unfairly penalising Queensland and Western Australia and it must take responsibility for the effect native title is having, creating the continuing uncertainty which will have disastrous medium- to long-term effectsâ

talk.start.para: âGoebbels running the biggest clearing house in Queensland.
âSenator Faulkner, you are sitting with your back to me, which is not really polite, and so is Senator Hillâ

interjection.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe statement I made was, `Senator Faulkner, you are sitting with your back to me as is Senator Hill,'âand if you had not shouted so much, you might have heard it. I resent your sitting with your back to me shouting, either of you.

âThe ALP must take responsibility for the continuing uncertainty which will have disastrous medium- to long-term effects in a reduction in exploration, no additional exports, no additional jobs in mining and no additional jobs in associated manufacturingâ(Time expired)

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am indebted to the minister for his answer, particularly in relation to the effect on jobs. I am concerned about jobs in North Queensland amongst Aboriginal communities. I ask the minister whether he is aware of a further legal challenge to the construction of the Gregory River Bridge and what effect that would have on the construction of the Century mine and jobs?

âIt is a great disappointment that native title issues are again impeding the Century Zinc project, following the successful completion of earlier protracted negotiations which senators will recall included the Hon. Bill Hayden, ex-Governor-General, who made scathing remarks about the Native Title Act. The construction of the Gregory River Bridge is essential to ensure access to the Century mine in the wet season. Because of the legal vulnerability of agreements made under the Native Title Act, this $1.2 billion project has again been called into question, even though it is widely supported by the local Aboriginal people and has received native title clearance to proceed. The current obstacles reinforce the government's view that the passage of the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2] is essential to secure agreed arrangements such as the Century proposal. It is yet another example of the inability of Labor senators opposite to put aside politics and consider the national interest, the interests of pastoralists, the interests of minersâparticularly small minersâand the local Aborigines, who have much to gain from this project. (Time expired)

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Has the minister been informed of the chaos in Katoomba in the electorate of Macquarie where, despite promises, there is no government jobs agency available? Is the minister aware that the CES office has shut and has a sign on the door telling job seekers to trudge half a kilometre away to what is now a non-existent Employment National office, hidden up a flight of stairs in a dingy building? Is the minister aware that when an Employment National office finally opens in Katoomba, it will only be available on Wednesdays from 9.30 a.m. until 3.30 p.m.? Can the minister explain how this is an improvement on the old CES, which was open and available to the people of Katoomba five days a week?

âI will certainly look into the point that Senator West raises. While I am answering this question, can I just say that there are some 1,400 sites which have replaced 296 sites formerly run by the CES so, across Australia, there is a many-fold increase in the number of sites available to job seekers. In relation to the particular instance Senator West has raised, I will look into that.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I refer to the longstanding claim by Dr Kemp that government schools would receive $2.3 billion more in the four years to the year 2000 than if the funding was held at 1996 levels. On 5 March, Dr Kemp said in parliament that this was $2 billionâa reduction of $300 million, or 13 per cent. Minister, yesterday you said there would be an extra $382 million a year spent on government schools. Australian parents are having difficulty believing the claims you make about increased spending on government schools at any time. Is Dr Kemp wrong, or how do you explain the disappearance of $300 million?

âWhat I said yesterday was that the increase for government schools over previous expenditure was $382 million this year, not per year. I think Senator Allison has got that wrong for a start. In relation to Dr Kemp's figure, he no doubt was referring to over a period of time and not in one particular year, so you cannot compare the figure that I mentioned yesterday with Dr Kemp's. What I can tell you is that the minister for education in New South Wales is certainly spreading a case of distortion and misconception when he says that we are cutting expenditure to schools in Australia.
âIn real terms that is right.
âNo, it is not. Totally, we are spending $382 million for the government sector and, in total for all schools, over $500 million more this year.
âIt is a declineâin real terms.

âThrough you, Madam President, I say to Senator Carr that we have an increase on Labor's last year of $382 million for the government sector this year and, when you bring in the non-government sector, it is more than $500 million. That includes added incentives for things like numeracy, literacy, civics in schools, the discovering democracy project and VET in schoolsâwhich is a new initiative which I note the Leader of the Opposition certainly did not mention when he addressed the AEU conference in New South Wales on the weekend. It is a very important issue which directly touches on at least 70 per cent of Australia's school children.

answer.para: I would say to you, Senator Allison through you, Madam President, is that you want to look more to what this government is doing by its new incentives and its new programs, and tell the people of Australia what the Democrats are going to do. What are you going to offer the students of Australia? Where are your policies for school programs? What are you going to do in relation to numeracy and literacy? I would ask the Democrats what they are going to do about vocational education and training in schools. The silence is deafening.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I did not get the figures wrong. I am quoting Dr Kemp, who has talked about $2.3 billion but, on 5 March, he revised this to $2 billion. I am asking you what happened to the $300 million. On the point of the question to me about what the Democrats would do, may I suggest that the minister might himself have attended the education conference last weekend, then perhaps he would have known. However, can I suggest that this may be a case of $2.3 billion being a rubbery figure in the first place. Doesn't the real figureâthat is, the $2 billionâmean that any increase is just inflation and that, per capita, private school funding is still increasing at a faster rate than that for government schools?

âI might Senator Allison of her use of figures when she talked about the 1996 unemployment figures for Bendigo. Senator Allison said that there was increasing rate of unemployment in Bendigo, which put it at the lower end of the scale. When you look at more recent figuresâ
âMadam President, I raise a point of order as to relevance. I did not raise questions about unemployment.

âOn the point of order: Senator Allison has called into question the use of figures by Dr Kemp and me. As part of my answer, I am referring to her lack of credibility in the use of figures. I think that is directly relevant.

âThere certainly was a lot in that question other than question. There was a lot of comment and it is difficult to suggest to the minister that he cannot make comment. I would ask you primarily to adhere to answering the question, Senator.

âOn the basis that Senator Allison has been the source of unreliable figures in the past, I would say that what she needs to do is to have a look at the positives of this government in relation to its educational program, particularly in relation to government schools and our increased funding thereof. When I see what the Democrats have to offer in relation to the schools of Australia, I will take them a bit more seriously.
âMy question is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Can the minister confirm that formal responsibility for federal government fundingâ

question.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Order on my right! Senator Parer is entitled to hear the question.

âI will start again. Can the minister confirm that formal responsibility for federal government funding for alternative energy sources such as ethanol production has been removed from the minister's duties by the Prime Minister? Can the minister also confirm that this action has been taken because of the continuing public perception that any statement or decision by the Minister for Resources and Energy is just not credible because of the minister's well-known conflicts of interest with his private shares and property interests in coal? Doesn't the Prime Minister's action in relation to ethanol funding add further weight to the clear impression that the Howard government Minister for Resources and Energy has no credibility on any resources matter whatsoever? In light of this fact, isn't it totally impossible for the minister to properly carry out his duties as minister?
âMadam President, isn't it extraordinary? Here we have these wild statements coming in about ethanol funding.

answer.para: Senator Stott Despoja interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âA good interjection from over there, Senator. This has been canvassed at great length. There were two parts to the ethanol funding scheme. I will talk about the substantive parts of it. One was a subsidy paid on ethanol itself which was to go to two groups, one in Mackay and the other one in Manildra. The other one was a contribution of moneys to an ethanol pilot plant to handle the production of woody wastes.

answer.para: The second one is, I think, the one Senator Conroy is referring to. I do not think Senator Conroy knows, Madam President, but at least the Democrats are aware of this, and I think Senator Brown is too. But Senator Conroy has no idea. He just wants to get up there and make these sorts of remarks that he has been trained to make by the organ-grinder up the back, Senator Robert Ray.

talk.start.para: âYes or no? Do you have responsibility or not?

âYou should read former Senator Richardson's book, Senator Conroy. I was interested in it because I could not help but noticeâI read it the other dayâthat he described his old tennis playing mate, Senator Robert Ray, as the most vicious man he ever met in parliament. Old Sid Vicious over there, Madam President.
âOrder! Senator, I invite your attention to the question.

interjection.para: Senator Conroy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Conroy, you can have a supplementary question if need be.

âI do not think Senator Conroy knows, but I think he is talking about the pilot plant. That was an amount of money of $2 million that was set aside to build a pilot plant in conjunction with equal amounts of money put up by industry and, I think, if my memory is correctâI stand to be corrected on thatâsomething from New South Wales. That program remains in place.
âYou wouldn't know what you're doing; you're too busy counting your money.
âWhich Pacific island are you going for a holiday on, Senator?

answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There is too much intervention in the chamber. Senators on both sides will cease interjecting.

âThe program to build a pilot plant has been continued in the last budget and as far as I know it is going ahead. I do not know what Senator Conroy is talking about in saying it has been taken from my responsibility. My understanding is that it has not. But, if it has, it is something that will be done in conjunction with me and Senator Hill.

âMinister, isn't this conflict of interest and your inability to make an unbiased decision on funding for the ethanol program the very reason for the complaining letter sent to you by your colleague the member for Gilmore, Joanna Gash, on 13 August 1996? Wasn't the member for Gilmore wasting her time drawing your attention to the moral dimension of reneging on agreements? When will the minister acknowledge, as the colleagues surrounding him have known for some time, that he is an absolute liability for the government and for his mate the Prime Minister?

âAgain Senator Conroy has got the whole matter totally confused. That is not surprising; he has got a confused little acolyte brain anyway. I think he is now talking about the ethanol bounty, which has been abandoned. It was a program that was abandonedâ

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Schacht.

interjection.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are senators on both sides shouting across the chamber. You are in breach of the standing orders and it is almost impossible to hearâand I am sure those at the end of the chamber cannot hearâSenator Parer's answer.

âIn the 1996 budget, bearing in mind we inherited the Beazley $10 billion deficit, which people on the other side denied for 2Â¼ years, one of the programs that fell out was the $20 million ethanol bounty. There was a departmental review of that bountyâas the Democrats would know, because at least they raised it in estimates, which people in the Labor Party did notâand we found that it could not be justified on environmental or economic grounds at that time.

âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts who seems to be making a welter of pressure on the ABC in recent times. Is the minister aware of threats to the ABC of legal action by mining or logging corporationsâ
âHope so.

âThe senator opposite says, `Hope so.' I hope not to the governmentâincluding threats involving intimidation with a view to achieving censored or biased reporting? What has been the cost to the ABC and the public purse of meeting such corporate threats? Moreover, what competitions, prizes or other incentives to listeners have been used by ABC radio commentators in Tasmania or elsewhere to foster the interests of industrial logging? Are such promotions consistent with an unbiased ABC?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am sure Senator Brown has got a fevered knowledge of these issues, but they have not been brought to my attention. They certainly were not canvassed with me by the ABC, either at any time prior to my meeting with the board this morning or during the course of that meeting. To ask whether there is any cost to the taxpayer or the budget as a result of measures that the ABC has to take to somehow ensure that it is not subject to pressure from mining and logging interests, all I can say is that assumes that such pressure is there and that the ABC is actually responding in the way that Senator Brown suggests. So I have no knowledge of any threats. Nothing has been brought to my attention. If there is something happening in the bowels of Tasmania that has got Senator Brown excited then I assume that he will probably bring it to my attention in due course.

âI ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I ask the minister: will he investigate whether the ABC has been subject to such threats by mining and logging corporations, what action has been taken and what the cost of meeting those threats has been? Secondly, will he investigate whether there have been incentives given to listeners in the promotion of industrial forestry in Tasmania or elsewhere?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: âOne of the joys of being an Independent senator or a senator from a minority party is that you have absolutely no prospect of ever having formal responsibility, but maybe Senator Brown could have a trial run.
âI rise on a point of order, Madam President. As Senator Alston knows full well, I am not an Independent senator. I represent the Australian Greens, Madam President.
âHe did refer to Independents or minor parties.

âI rise on a point of order, Madam President. Senator Brown has just misled the Senate because on the Tasmanian ballot paper he was registered as a Tasmanian Green, yet whenever he comes up here he tries to parade himself as an Australian Green. You had better make up your mind.
âThere is no point of order.

âMadam President, we may be accused of many things but I do not think we can do much to help resolve Senator Brown's identity crisis. If he does want intensive counselling then I am sure there are plenty of people available to help him. Can I simply suggest that if he wants a dry run as a minister, what he ought to do is actually sit down and write a letter to the ABC, or even pick up a telephone, and ask them what the facts are.
âWhy don't you?

âBecause no-one has brought it to my attention. If you think I am going to proceed on the basis of what you say in this place somehow constitutes a factual statement, then I can assure you that I have better things to do with my time. If you ascertain the facts and you present themâ

answer.para: Senator Forshaw interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI will tell you shortlyâyou may then be in a position to say that there is a requirement for further action to be taken in a formal sense. But do your homework first, get hold of the facts, see if there really is an issue, and then we might be able to help you later. (Time expired)

âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Isn't it true that the Australian Taxation Office has found that around 100,000 trusts have declared $26 billion in income, yet claimed $1 billion in losses? Isn't it also the case that the vast majority of trusts were established to avoid paying tax? Why is it that the government continues to shy away from forcing high-wealth individuals who use trusts, such as Senator Parer, to pay their fair share of taxation?

âThank you for that question, Senator Cook. In relation to the particular statistics you quoted, you would appreciate the fact that I would always want to check them carefully, particularly as they come from you, Senator Cook. I will check those figures to see whether the matters you stated are in fact correct.

answer.para: In relation to trusts generally, Senator Cook, you will be aware there has been a very prolonged debate in this chamber on trusts, trust losses and the taxation of trusts. It was intriguing to us all that suddenly the Labor Party, after 13 years in office, discovered that from their point of view there were some problems with trusts. I suspect that if we looked we would find that a great number of the trusts were established during Labor's term of office.
