Unproclaimed LegislationâDocument providing details of all provisions of Acts which come into effect on proclamation and which have not been proclaimed, including statements of reasons for their non-proclamation and information relating to the timetable for their operation as at 1 May 1998.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 11 March 1998.

question.para: Can details be provided including the name of the proponent, the title and nature of the project or transaction, the date of application, the date of approval, the value of the project or transaction and the value of the insurance provided of any resource project or transaction which the Export Finance Investment Corporation has approved for support since 1 October 1997, with regard to; (a) mining projects: (b) mineral shipments; (c) export woodchip shipments; (d) dams; and (e) renewable energy industries.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: During the period 1 October 1997 to 28 February 1998 the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC):

(a) approved a facility for one mining project: an export finance guarantee relating to the expansion and upgrading of the existing Sarcheshmeh copper smelter in Iran. If this project proceeds, EFIC expects an exposure of A$32.5m;

(b)approved insurance cover for mineral shipments as detailed in the Table attached. The row headed `Total Amount Approved' represents the total value of the export contract or invoice. EFIC's liability in the event of a claim would be a proportion of this amount. Often the liability would be 90% of the listed figure, but the liability could be as low as 50%. In addition, exporters may not have utilised the cover (or all of the cover) offered;

(c) did not receive information from exporters which permits it to identify whether the export was of woodchip. The information available related to all exports that the exporter has identified under the category of `wood and wood products';
(d) did not offer any facilities relating to dams;
(e) is not able to identify `renewable energy industries'.
The names of proponents of projects, exporters or buyers are commercial-in-confidence.
Attachment
EFIC SUPPORTED ACTIVITIESâRESOURCE BASED
(Export Credit Insurance and Confirming Bank)

entry.para: Romania, South Korea, Cayman Islands, Italy, and Germany.
Indonesia, Vietnam, South Korea, China and Pakistan.
South Korea, Indonesia, Taiwan, Turkey, China, Pakistan, Hong Kong, and Germany.
Denmark, Fiji, Thailand, China, South Korea and Japan.
South Korea, Indonesia, Taiwan, United States, Brazil, China, United Kingdom, Colombia, India, Hungary, Turkey.
South Korea, China, Hong Kong, United States, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Austria, United Kingdom, and Thailand

answer.para: NATIONAL INTEREST
SPECIFIC
Note: Mineral shipments are defined as any `ore' or `mineral sand'. If the ore underwent any process, it is not included.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 30 March 1998:

question.para: (1) What amount, in real terms and as a percentage of overall spending, of Natural Heritage Trust funding has been spent on administration, including salaries, sitting fees, consultancies, travel, accommodation and other support, at the; (a) national level; (b) state level; and (c) regional level.
(2) What amount, in real terms and as a percentage of overall spending, has been spent on promotion, including printing, advertising and consultancies.
(3) What steps are required for local government to receive funding.

(4) Is it a fact that some applications, including from local government, have not received funding until close to, or past, the closing date for next year's applications; if so, how can they be fairly expected to show that money received for the previous year has been properly spent.
(5) What proportion of Natural Heritage Trust spending is allocated to local government in: (a) rural Australia; and (b) urban Australia.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) At the national level, Environment Australia has been allocated $9.761 million for 1996-97 and 1997-98 which represents 4.3 per cent of the Trust funds for those years on administration and other support costs. In relation to programs administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the honourable senator may wish to direct this question to my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
(b) $210,000 has been approved for administrative and support costs to Tasmania for 1997-98, and negotiations are continuing with other States.

(c) No specific administrative assistance has been provided at the regional level, although some projects have administrative elements included in their total budgets. Extracting these costs from all projects would represent an unreasonable diversion of resources.

(2) Environment Australia has spent $560,541, which represents 0.25 per cent of Trust expenditure on promotion related activities for the Trust as a whole. Education activities undertaken by Trust programs are not included. In relation to programs administered by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the honourable senator may also wish to direct this question to my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
(3) Local Government can receive funding by applying through the advertised call for projects each year.

(4) For programs within my Portfolio, the vast majority of payments for the first One Stop Shop funding round had been made by Environment Australia to the States or proponents well before the advertised closing date for applications for the Natural Heritage Trust in 1998-99. In any case, Environment Australia will take into account the date at which proponents received funding when reviewing the progress of projects, to ensure that proponents are not disadvantaged.
(5) Local Governments are the lead proponent for projects funded in 1997-98 under the Natural Heritage Trust as follows:
Rural/Provincial 3.7 per cent of the first round of announced 1997-98 NHT funding
Urban 0.7 per cent of the first round of announced 1997-98 NHT funding.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 2 April 1998:

question.para: In relation to the Government's ministerial code of conduct:
(1) What is the definition of `conflict of interest'.
(2) what is the definition of `corruption'.

talk.start.para: âThe Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Neither the present government nor its predecessor has adopted a code of conduct and the narrow interpretations a code can encompass. The Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility and the rules on the registration of interests by ministers do not provide definitions of `conflict of interest' or `corruption' but require ministers to make judgements in relation to their own situations. All ministers are expected to behave honestly and avoid giving the appearance of using public office for private purposes.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs: Qualitative and Quantitative Research
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1144)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 17 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Given that nine departments have now answered in full the questions placed on notice on 16 October 1997 (questions on notice 902-916, Senate Notice Paper of 21 October 1997) relating to qualitative and quantitative research, on what basis was it decided that the department would not authorise the money, time and effort involved to assemble the information required to provide an answer to the question.
(2) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(3) (a) What was the nature of the research undertaken, (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation); and (b) to whom were the results of the research available.
(4) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(5) In each instance what has been the cost of the work undertaken.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The basis for deciding that the department would not authorise the money, time and effort to fully answer Question 914 was that retrieving the information requested by the Senator, would require considerable resources that would be more appropriately devoted to other tasks centrally related to administering the government's programs.
It should be noted that much of the information that is requested by the Senator is already available in the Department's annual reports.
(2), (3), (4) and (5) For the reason outlined in answer to part (1) of the Senator's question I am not prepared to ask my department to divert their resources at this time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 23 April 1998:

question.para: With reference to the Commonwealth Employment Service offices closed since March 1996:
(1) (a) How many sites were owned by the Commonwealth; and (b) how many were leased.

(2) For each of the leased sites: (a) in which State and suburb/town is the site located; (b) what is the unexpired period of the lease; (c) what is the lettable space involved; and (d) what is the cost of the unexpired period of the lease or of buying out the lease.
(3) For each of the owned sites, if any, what does the Commonwealth intend to do with the site.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Twenty-eight Commonwealth Employment Service Offices were closed between March 1996 and 23 April 1998. Of those offices: (a) One site was owned by the Commonwealth; and (b) 27 sites were leased by the Commonwealth.

(2) The attached list provides details of the location and lettable space for each of the closed offices. The only site which has an unexpired lease period is Nambour. This site has been sublet and the net financial cost to the Commonwealth for the remainder of the lease (lease expiry date 31 March 2001) is $22,278, which represents less than 5% of the outstanding commitment.
(3) The Granville office which was owned by the Commonwealth has now been sold to private investors as part of the Government's program to rationalise Commonwealth owned property.

subdebateinfo.title: Department for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs: Advertising
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1162)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 23 April 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the value of advertising placed by: (a) the department; and (b) agencies within the Minister's portfolio, on a month-by-month basis since March 1996.

(2) What proportion of advertising placed by the department or portfolio agencies since March 1996 has been for: (a) print media; (b) radio; (c) television; or (d) other, and give details of other forms of advertising used.

(3) (a) What proportion of advertising placed by the department or portfolio agencies since March 1996 has been placed through the Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA); and (b) what mechanism has been used for that advertising not placed through OGIA.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: To answer this question would involve a large amount of resources. I do not consider that such extensive replies are an appropriate use of resources otherwise available for developing and providing services to the public. I am not prepared to authorise the use of these resources to provide the information you have requested on this occasion.
